_prev_prog_3.Description:
The primary function of the oil movements and storage area is to facilitate the storage of all feed and products at the refinery. There are four distinct sub-areas in the OM&S process:

(i) North Oil Movement (NOM)

(ii) East Oil Movement (EOM)

(iii) Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG)

(iv) Railcars / Trucks

The unit also includes the butane storage areas, the caustic unit, and the racks.

_prev_prog_3.PHA_OtherTechnique: Simplified LOPA without conditional modifiers (Risk ranking)

_prev_prog_3.Description:
The function of the fluidized catalytic cracking (FCC) unit is to convert low value heavy gas oils to more valuable lighter fractions, primarily gasoline, through catalytic cracking process. The unit takes sweet vacuum gas oil from the hydrotreater unit and from storage, and light gas oil from the hydrotreater unit. The unit produces considerable volumes of butane-butylene, and propane-propylene, in addition to clarified slurry oil (CSO) and light cycle oil (LCO).



The primary function of the unsaturated gas plant is to separate gasoline range hydrocarbons into gasoline and Liquid Petroleum Gas (LPG). The unit stabilizes the FCC gasoline by removing the light gaseous hydrocarbons from it and removes H2S from the olefinic LPG.The products from the unsaturated gas plant are the gasoline, olefin LPG, and fuel gas.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Introduction and Policies

The Torrance Refining Company has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety and protecting the environment. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of the refinery's processes. The objective is to implement effective controls to prevent releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, the refinery's trained personnel will respond to control, contain, and mitigate the release.



The refinery Process Safety Management System (PSMS) framework establishes expectations for controlling operations integrity risks inherent in its business. PSMS addresses all aspects of the business that can impact safety, health and process safety performance. PSMS encompasses all elements of OSHA's Process Safety Management standard and EPA's Risk Management Program.



2. Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

Torrance Refining Company, LLC, located in Torrance, California, U.S.A., operates a variety of processes to produce petroleum products (e.g. propane, butane, gasoline products, jet fuels, diesel fuels, asphalt and coke) from crude oil. The refinery contains a threshold quantity of several regulated flammable substances and one toxic substance, hydrofluoric acid (HF). Anhydrous ammonia is also in use in one process, but in quantities less than the threshold quantity of 10,000 lbs.



In accordance with 40 CFR 68.150, in 2014 the refinery prepared a 5-year update to the previous Risk Management Plan (RMP). Updates were done in 2016 to account for two 2015 RMP reportable incidents at the refinery. The refinery contains a total of eleven covered processes for the purpose of this report. Each process is listed below along with the category of regulated materials contained within the process:



Process 1: DIB Butane Processing - Flammables

Process 2: Fuel Gas Treatment - Fla

mmables

Process 3: Hydrogen Plant #2 - Flammables

Process 4: MHF Alkylation - Flammables, Toxics (HF Acid)

Process 5: Hydrocracker - Flammables

Process 6: Hydrotreater - Flammables

Process 7: North Coker - Flammables

Process 8: Oil Movements & Storage - Flammables

Process 9: Saturated Gas Plant - Flammables

Process 10: South Coker - Flammables

Process 11: FCC & Unsaturated Gas Plant - Flammables

Process 12: LPG Merox - Flammables



3. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at the refinery. The Torrance Refinery Process Safety Management System (PSMS) consist of 21 elements that make up the PSMS.  These 21 elements address the various requirements of the EPA Risk Management Program.  Each element of the PSMS has a Sponsor and Administrator whom have the responsibility of understanding the regulatory requirements addressed by element, ensuring their element provides the appropriate framework for the refinery to implement and sustain compliance, and providing feedback on their element to the Process Safety Management Committee (PSMC).  All 21 PSMS elements have a system plan which shapes the methodology, standards and practices for that specific element.



The Process Safety Management Committee (PSMC) is comprised of both represented employees, such as the USW Process Safety Representative and the USW Co-Chair of the Joint Health and Safety Committee (JHSC) and different levels of site management.  The PSMC is responsible for implementing the PSMS, reviewing the effectiveness of the PSMS elements, and encouraging continuous improvement of the elements.



Torrance Refinery has the PSMS Mapping Document which identifies the PSMS elements, their assigned Sponsor and Administrator, the regulatory topic, and the applicable regulatory citations relevant to that specific element.  The purpose of the PSMS Mapping document is to clearly identify the responsible p

ersonnel for each PSMS element.



The following shows  the framework the PSMS at the refinery has  to address each element of the General Accidental Release Prevention Program:



?    PSMS 1.1 Management Leadership, Commitment and Accountability

?    PSMS 2.1 Risk Assessment and Management;

?    PSMS 3.1 Facility Design and Construction

?    PSMS 4.1 Documentation and Information

?    PSMS 5.1 Personal Safety

?    PSMS 5.2 Occupational Health

?    PSMS 5.3 Personnel

?    PSMS 5.4 Training

?    PSMS 6.1A Operations Procedures

?    PSMS 6.1B Maintenance Procedures

?    PSMS 6.2 Work Permits / Hotwork

?    PSMS 6.3 Safety Critical Equipment

?    PSMS 6.4 Mechanical Integrity

?    PSMS 6.6 Regulatory Compliance

?    PSMS 6.7 Operations Interface Management

?    PSMS 7.1 Management of Change

?    PSMS 8.1 Third Party Services

?    PSMS 9.1 Incident Investigation 

?    PSMS 10.1 Emergency Preparedness

?    PSMS 10.2 Community Awareness

?    PSMS 11.1 Assessment and Improvement



Employee Participation:

The refinery encourages employees to participate in process safety management and accident prevention. Examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling operating and maintenance procedures to participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team and the Process Safety Management Committee. Employees have access to information created as part of the refinery accident prevention program. The Employee Participation Plan includes participation by the Joint Health & Safety Committee which consists of employees from Management (salaried), the USW (United Steel Workers) representatives and the IBEW (International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers) representatives.



Process Safety Information:

The refinery keeps a variety of documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information.

Specific groups within the refinery are assigned responsibility for maintaining up-to-date process safety information.



Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment consideration, is provided in safety data sheets (SDSs). This information is supplemented by documents that specifically address known corrosion concerns and any known hazards associated with the inadvertent mixing of chemicals. For specific process areas, the refinery has identified Operating Envelopes; i.e. documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters such as temperature, level, pressure, flow and compositions. The refinery ensures that the process is maintained within these limits using computerized process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel, and protective systems both passive and active (e.g., automated shutdown systems, alarm systems, pressure relieving systems, dikes, pressure vessel design, and technology.



Information about the design and construction of process equipment includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, and electrical rating of equipment. This information, in combination with maintenance procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.



Process Hazard Analysis:

The refinery has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled. Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.

The refinery primarily uses the Guide Word Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study that is an adaptation of widely used industry methodologies to perform these evaluations. Guide Word HAZOP analysis is recognized as a syste

matic and thorough hazard evaluation technique and the refinery uses the Layers of Protection Analysis (LOPA) methodology in the PHA analysis. These analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating experience and engineering expertise on the process to be evaluated. The PHA team identifies and evaluates hazards on the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary.



Operating Procedures:

The refinery maintains procedures that address modes of process operations, such as:

? Startup

? Shutdown

? Normal

? Temporary



These procedures are used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a consistent basis for training of new operators. The procedures are kept current and accurate by reviewing them periodically, and revising them as necessary to reflect changes made through the management of change process. These procedures are annually certified as current and accurate.



The refinery has identified Operating Envelopes; i.e., documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters such as temperature, level, pressure, flow, and compositions. This information, along with written operating procedures, is readily available to operators in the process unit and for other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job tasks.



Training:

To complement the written procedures for process operations, the refinery has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process. New employees receive basic training in refinery operations. After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with an experienced operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks. After employees demonstrate (e.g., through tests, skills demonstrations) they have adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they can wor

k independently.



Training is also provided for each employee involved in maintaining the ongoing integrity of process equipment. This training includes an overview of the refining process and its hazards. Training is provided on specific procedures applicable to the employee's job tasks to assure that the employees can perform the job tasks in a safe manner.



Contractors:

The refinery uses contractors to supplement its workforce. Contractors are contractually obligated to adhere to all safety rules and practices applicable to Torrance Refining Company employees. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the refinery has a system in place to ensure that contractors:

? perform their work in a safe manner

? have the appropriate knowledge and skills

? are aware of the hazards in their work area

? understand what they should do in the event of an emergency

? understand and follow site safety rules

? inform refinery personnel of any hazards that they find during work.



In addition, the refinery evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during the selection of a contractor. Refinery personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations.



Mechanical Integrity:

The refinery has well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, control instruments, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include:

? conducting applicable training

? developing maintenance procedures

? performing inspections and tests

? correcting identified deficiencies

? applying quality assurance measures.



In combination, those activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment. Maintenance personnel receive training on:

? overview of the processes

? safety and health hazards

? applicable maintenance procedure

s

? emergency response plans

? applicable safe work practices to help ensure they can perform their job in a safe manner



Maintenance procedures help ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training. Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended, and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels). If a deficiency is identified, employees will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service (if possible), or else the equipment use will be reviewed to determine what actions are necessary to ensure the continued safe operation of the equipment.



Another integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance. The refinery incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs. This helps ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used and available when repairs are made.



Safe Work Practices:

The refinery has long-standing safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety. These include orientations for visitors/contractors, control of the entry/exit of support personnel, energy isolation for equipment being worked on, procedures for the safe removal of hazardous materials before opening of process piping/equipment, hot work permit/procedure to safely manage spark-producing activities, control of vehicle entry into process area, confined space entry permit/procedure to help ensure precautions are taken before entering confined spaces, and job hazard analyses to identify and mitigate hazards associated with maintenance tasks. These practices, along with related procedures and training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure operations and maintenance activities are performed safely. These safety procedures and practices are posted on on the TORC sharepoint site and available

to all employees.



Management of Change:

The refinery has a comprehensive Management of Change system. This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology, procedures, and other facility changes are properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. Changes are reviewed to:

?    Ensure hazards associated with the change are identified and evaluated

?    Ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards

?    Verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change

?    Ensure that process safety information, including chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated to incorporate these changes

?    Ensure changes are properly communicated to operations and maintenance personnel, and, that any necessary training is completed before the change is implemented



Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information as well as procedures, are updated to incorporate these changes. In addition, operations and maintenance personnel are notified, and provided any necessary training before the change is implemented.



Incident Investigation:

The refinery promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in catastrophic release. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to refinery management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are resolved.



Compliance Audits:

To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, the refinery periodically conducts audits to determine whether the procedures and practices required

by the refinery's accident prevention program are being properly implemented. Compliance audits are conducted at least every 3 years. The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to refinery management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are complete. 



In addition, a periodic internal assessment of refinery management systems is conducted to ensure they are functioning as intended. Work plans are developed and tracked for systems where the assessment team has identified improvement opportunities.



4. Five-Year Accident History

In the last 5 years, the refinery has experienced two accidental releases as defined by 40 CFR Part 68.42. Each of these accidental releases met the 40 CFR Part 68.42 definition because they resulted in sheltering-in-place for offsite populations as detailed below:



? 2/18/15 - A rapid overpressure occurred in the FCC 2D-17/18 electrostatic precipitator (ESP) on the FCC unit. No employees or contractors sustained a Cal OSHA Recordable injury as a result of the event. Emergency response by refinery personnel was immediate.

? 10/23/15 - A leak of primarily steam from an outlet header of Coker Heater 21F-8 was discovered. No employees or contractors sustained a Cal OSHA Recordable injury as a result of the event. Emergency response by refinery personnel was immediate.



5. Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

The processes at the refinery include inherent hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation. The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to all covered processes at the refinery. Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human error.



In addition to the accident prevention program activities, the refinery has safety features on many units to help (1) quickly detect a release, (2) contain/control a release and (3) reduce t

he consequences of (mitigate) a release. The safety features used within various processes include but are not limited to:



Release Detection:

? Hydrocarbon detectors with alarms

? Hydrofluoric acid detectors with alarms

? CCTV surveillance cameras

? H2S detectors with alarms



Release Containment/Control:

? Pressure relief valves that discharge to a flare for safe disposal

? Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual or automated)

? Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high level, high temperature)

? Curbing or diking to contain liquid releases

? Redundant equipment and instrumentation

? Atmospheric relief devices



Release Mitigation:

? Fire suppression and extinguishing systems

? Deluge system for specific equipment

? Trained emergency response personnel

? Personal protective equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus)

? Blast-resistant buildings to help protect personnel and control systems



MHF Acid Specific Prevention Steps:

The refinery has always had risk management programs that are specific to the MHF alkylation process to address prevention, early detection, and mitigation. Since 1999, additional enhanced risk management strategies have been implemented to supplement these historical programs. The following are specific programs and technologies that have been implemented on the MHF Alkylation Unit at the Torrance Refinery:

? MHF acid additive technology to minimize aerosol formation during a release

? HF acid electrochemical detectors to provide quick notification of a release

? Remote emergency block valving to isolate a leak

? Remotely activated rapid acid transfer to an acid evacuation vessel located away from the main processing unit behind a concrete blast wall

? Physical barriers surrounding key acid-containing equipment to enhance liquid rainout of any MHF release

? Flexible barriers around all flanges in concentrated acid service to enhance liquid rainou

t of any MHF release

? CCTV video capabilities that include digital recording and playback

? External HF alkylation safety audits by experienced multi-discipline teams

? Remotely operated high volume water monitors to aid in vapor suppression

? Remote water monitor controls at the refinery central control building

? Unit perimeter HF detection system using line of sight technology (Laser)

? Acid sensitive paint



6. Emergency Response Program

The refinery maintains a written emergency response program, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to a loss of containment, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including: proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures; evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation; notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs; and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. In addition, the refinery has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment. Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to refinery processes or other refinery facilities.



The overall emergency response program for the refinery is in conformance with NIMS and is coordinated with the City of Torrance Fire Department. The refinery conducts periodic emergency drills with the fire department and has around-the-clock communications capability with officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., City of Torrance Fire Department). This provides a means of both notifying the public about an incident as

well as facilitating quick refinery response to an incident.



7. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The Process Safety Management System forms the cornerstone for continuous improvement in the refinery's safety-related systems. Under PSMS 11.1 Assessments and Improvements, these systems are kept evergreen and are in a continuous state of improvement, usually through improvement steps such as implementation of recommendations from hazard reviews and any incident investigations. Some specific examples of these steps include enhancing the site's verification and validation activities to ensure corrective actions properly address the findings and recommendations from hazard review & investigations; and increasing the effectiveness of critical procedures, alarms, and other integrated systems.
